title: How to find the equation of the tangent that intersects a circle (x+1) ^2 +(y-2) ^2=100 at point P (5,10) - Quora

response.answer_text: A2A: How do I find the equation of the tangent that intersects a circle (x+1) ^2 +(y-2) ^2=100 at point P (5,10)? Answer: [math]\ 3x+4y=55[/math] Let's do this the easy way, with vectors. From the equation, we know that the center of the circle is at (-1,2). From there, we move to the point (5,10) via the direction vector (5,10)-(-1,2)=(6,8). Now we must either turn left or right and move an arbitrary distance to be on the tangent line. To turn, we need a negative reciprocal of the direction vector. [math]\quad\begin{array}{cl}  & \binom{x}{y}=\binom{-1}{2}+\binom{6}{8}+t\binom{-8}{6}\\ \Rightarrow & \boxed{\binom{x}{y}=\binom{5}{10}+t\binom{-8}{6};\quad t\in\mathbb{R}} \end{array}[/math] Now that we have an equation for the tangent line in vector form, we can change it to x:y form. [math]\qquad\begin{array}{ccccc} \begin{array}{l} x=5-8t\\ y=10+6t \end{array} & \Rightarrow & \begin{array}{l} 3x=15-24t\\ 4y=40+24t \end{array} & \Rightarrow & \boxed{3x+4y=55}\end{array}[/math]
